Award.AwardTitle: Biotechnology in American High Schools: Continuing Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cold Spring Harbor DNA Learning Center (DNALC) conducted a nationwide survey of high school biology teachers in 1998 to collect data on the penetration of biotechnology/molecular genetics in American High Schools. The DNALC possesses other related unique datasets that represent biology teachers who have since retired. The proposed survey provides an opportunity to compare two generations of biology teachers with respect to laboratory instruction and students exposure to four major techniques: bacterial transformation, DNA restriction analysis, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and DNA sequencing. The 1998 study showed that the early adoption of biotechnology lab instruction was concentrated in schools located in high wealth, suburban zip codes. It is important to see if, today, hands-on biotechnology instruction has broadened to include economically challenged and more diverse urban populations. It may also be possible to correlate changes in teacher attitudes and behavior with funding and educational trends over this period of time, including NSF's and HHMI's shift away from teacher professional development institutes and the increased standardized testing under No Child Left Behind. In this way, the study results may provide insights for educational policy and future efforts in teacher professional development.

In the first quarter of 2018 an email survey was conducted with the goal of reproducing the sample size, number of respondents, and response rate from the 1998 study. Although the sample size was comparable (approximately 12,000 teachers), the email-based method yielded a much lower response rate (10% in 2018 versus 30% in 1998). To ensure that the study will capture a representative snapshot of U.S. biology teachers, this project will re-administer the survey via the U.S. Postal Service, with the objective of improving the response rate, and increasing the sample size to confirm the initial findings from the email survey. Initial findings include: laboratory teaching in biotechnology has been brought "to scale" in a number of U.S. schools over the last 20 years, the two cohorts of biology teachers have different perceptions of constraints that limit their ability to incorporate new concepts and techniques into their classes, relatively few schools that currently offer molecular biology electives seem to be involved in the school-to-work movement advocated by the ATE program, the current cohort appears to be less professional and less involved than the 1998 cohort, and summer institutes and workshops remain the most important contributors to teacher expertise; however, formal education is much more significant for the current cohort. The project will re-administer the survey using letters and reminders sent by U.S. Postal Service to increase number of respondents and collect retrospective data on the numbers of teachers trained in intensive workshops from 1988 to 2018 to analyze the impact of the reduced numbers of teacher professional development workshops supported by the NSF and HHMI since 2012.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this ATE project was to understand changes in biotechnology instruction over the last thirty years through the administration of a nationwide teacher survey. The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) emphasize that students learn science best by actually engaging in science themselves, but engaging in hands-on, biotechnology-focused lab work is not a mandated element of high school science coursework nationwide. As a result, we set out to document variation in high school biotechnology education and understand the influences on teachers who choose to integrate biotechnology and molecular biology into their existing courses.

There are six core molecular biology labs that are commonly taught in American high schools. These include bacterial transformation, restriction analysis, DNA recombination, plasmid isolation, polymerase chain reaction, and DNA sequencing. Our survey, administered in spring 2018, asked questions of participating teachers about these labs and courses they taught, the number of students they reached, their participation in professional development, and their attitudes about science and science teaching. In addition to the 2018 survey, we have comparative survey data from a nationwide survey administered in 1998. It is the 1998 survey that forms the core of the 2018 survey, and as a result we are able to track how biotechnology instruction has evolved over this twenty year period and where it should go in the future.

Analysis of data collected from more than 2,000 high school biology teachers revealed that biotechnology education has changed, but not always for the better. Fewer teachers seem to be using the six core labs in their courses, but more students are being reached in 2018, indicating that the teachers who do use these materials are comfortable using them in a variety of courses and with students of differing abilities. More schools are offering biotechnology-focused courses, too, which is a big shift from twenty years ago. While the offering of biotechnology electives has increased, there is still not substantial integration of school-to-work initiatives, including use of biotechnology-driven curriculum materials and the development of articulation agreements with 2- and 4-year colleges.

In addition to changes in the schools, the types of activities undertaken by teachers outside of the classroom have changed. In 1998, more teachers were engaged in activities related to professional development. This includes membership in professional societies, attendance at professional meetings, and presenting new and innovative lab techniques in a variety of settings. Overall, teachers are spending fewer hours on professional development and relying less on time-intensive trainings to improve their skills than the teachers twenty years ago.

The twenty year comparison featured in this project was augmented by archival research in the National Science Foundation abstract archives. What we found mirrored the decline in participation in extracurricular and professional development activities. NSF-funded biology teacher training opportunities peaked in 1992, and in a twenty year period dropped from 92 programs to a mere five. This coincides with the sense from today's teachers that there are not as many opportunities for training at workshops and summer institutes. Teachers indicated that they still find these types of trainings critical for their own learning. This suggests that improving teacher preparation for biotechnology education may require a reinvestment in these types of intensive training opportunities.

Ultimately, this project has tracked changes in pedagogy, curriculum, and attitudes surrounding biotechnology and molecular biology education over the course of thirty years. These data have allowed us to pinpoint precisely how biotechnology education has changed as biology has transitioned out of the age of the gene and into the age of the genome, and provide a blueprint for the future direction of high school biotechnology education.
